Articles.Content:
So I landed Jeb on the Mun today. And, um, any landing you can walk away from is a good landing, right? Not so sure... We landed on a bit of a slope. Jeb got out and planted his flag without incident. But when he went to climb the ladder back onto his spaceship, damned if the thing didn't topple over.

I guess you best start walking, Jeb ol' boy.

Threads like these are always better with a screenshot.

Make sure to land your rescue craft on flat ground, eh?

must... not... say... "and Tyler too"

damn it

Edited August 14, 2013 by AfailingHORSE

must... not... say... "and Tyler too"

damn it

Crap, you beat me to it.
Well, I know that there are at least four oldsters in this thread.
I agree, need to see a screenie of the landing!

Well, I know that there are at least four oldsters in this thread.

Make that, "... at least five oldsters in this thread."

Make that, "... at least five oldsters in this thread."

How about six?
Well, at least you don't have a tippy canoe on Tylo too. That would really suck to do a rescue from.

I don't think anyone alive today technically gets the reference in its first form, since I'm pretty sure nobody alive today was around in 1840, but yeah. I get it, mostly because of my parents.

Landers are remarkably unlike London buses. It's generally inadvisable to park them on any slope with a grade steeper than 10 degrees.

must... not... say... "and Tyler too"

damn it

grrrrr I wanted to say that.

I don't think anyone alive today technically gets the reference in its first form, since I'm pretty sure nobody alive today was around in 1840, but yeah. I get it, mostly because of my parents.

Landers are remarkably unlike London buses. It's generally inadvisable to park them on any slope with a grade steeper than 10 degrees.

Depend on the lander design.

This one would be very hard to tip over.

Yes its Dress canyon, the slope was so steep you could not walk back to the lander.
